DOC.detailed_description: Rationale & background information Transcutaneous Electric Nervous Stimulation ( TENS ) extensively use pain relief . Notably , Ultra Low Frequency TENS ( ULF-TENS ) use research dentistry reliable tool diagnosis treatment temporomandibular disorder ( TMD ) . The mechanism action TENS widely investigate involves local systemic effect . In particular , experiment use animal model show systemic action trough involvement autonomic nervous system ( ANS ) . Endogenous opioid descend pain modulatory system think involved central activation TENS stimulation . In particular , pain modulation occur via endogenous opioids affect periaqueductal gray ( PAG ) rostral ventromedial medulla ( RVM ) brain region . The PAG provide neuroanatomical neuro-functional substrate couple cortical outflow adequate autonomic response . To study ANS activity response condition rest stress , heart rate variability ( HRV ) breathe rate ( BR ) traditionally use experiment due repeatability reliability . To study TENS effect autonomic nervous system , HRV use ; however , pupillometry , skin conductance , blood flow skin temperature , also reliable indicator use study ANS . Data support hypothesis TENS could act peripheral autonomic effector via sympathovagal balance PAG-opioid activity . Moreover , suggest PAG participate medial viscero-motor network represent link emotional cognitive function manage autonomic support . In particular , neuro-connections successfully investigate use HRV . The goal present study investigate effect TENS stimulation peripheral autonomic behavior ULF-TENS stimulation . It hypothesize TENS reduces peripheral autonomic index . Study goal objectives The goal present proposal investigate ANS effect ULF-TENS stimulation patient without TMD conduct observational RTC . The enrolled subject ( without TMD ) randomly assign case control group . The case group receive total 40 minute TENS stimulation , whereas control group . DOC.criteria: myogenous TMD ; pain duration longer 3 month ; presence complete permanent dentition , possible exception third molar ; normal occlusion .
